Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark 'BEST CANADIAN MOTOR INNS & Design' is clearly descriptive under section 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from decision of the Trade-marks Opposition Board to the Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Design elements were considered, but dominant words found to be clearly descriptive; new expert evidence on distinctiveness did not alter outcome
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate trademark is registrable
Credibility_Factor: Expert evidence submitted but not sufficient to overcome descriptiveness finding
Legal_Rule: Section 12(1)(b) prohibits registration of clearly descriptive trademarks
Procedural_Issue: Appeal under section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Outcome_on_Merits: Trademark found clearly descriptive; registration refused
Decision_Maker: Trade-marks Opposition Board (initial), Federal Court (on appeal)
Key_Evidence_Considered: Visual and phonetic impression of the mark
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, including sections 12(1)(b) and 56
Applicant_Challenge: Registration of 'BEST CANADIAN MOTOR INNS & Design' for hotel and restaurant services
Court_Result: Dismissed with costs awarded to Respondent
Defendant_Response: Opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness and confusion
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of registration of allegedly descriptive mark
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative opposition followed by judicial appeal
Applicable_Process: Opposition proceeding under Trade-marks Act, followed by appeal
